PI: Tryggvason

Direct numerical simulations (DNS) have made significant contribution to our understanding of multiphase flows over the last two decades. As their use has increased, and increasingly complex systems are being examined, two major issues have emerged. The first is that in many situations small-scale features emerge that require excessive (and often unachievable) resolution. These features either emerge spontaneously as thin films or threads or due to the addition of new physics that takes place on time and length scales very different than those of the flow. The second issue is that the wealth of data generated by DNS now far outstrips what can be used in standard models for the average flow field. This project is aimed at addressing both issues through the following two objectives. (1) The use of embedded analytical description for accurate capture of topology changes in simulations of multiphase flows. The approach is based on the observation that many small-scale features (films, threads, boundary layers, etc.) have a relatively simple structure and can therefore be described relatively accurately by analytical or semi-analytical models that are evolved concurrently with the fully resolved larger-scale motion. In this project, earlier work of films and mass transfer will be extended to capture accurately the rupture of films and threads. (2) Explore the evolution of various advanced statistical ways to describe the topology of complex multiphase flows. Such quantities include the area concentration tensor, average surface tension effects, and others, yet to be determined. The goal is to establish how these quantities correlate with the structure of the flow, and to attempt to model their evolution. Particular attention will be focused on how these quantities change during topology changes, their influence on the overall evolution of the flow, and the importance of predicting rupture accurately. The numerical methods will be made available through an online repository, along with a thorough documentation of the methodology and the use of the codes.

Multiphase flows are critical in energy conversion, material processing, chemical industry, atmospheric processes, and living systems. Incremental improvement in the efficiency of such processes translates into billions of dollars in savings and new discoveries have the potential to transform whole industries. Computational studies will bring about both incremental and transformative changes in the management of multiphase systems. Educational material aimed at lowering the barrier to entry for new researchers will be developed and undergraduate students will be exposed to the area through research projects.

This project is partially funded by an CISE/ACI CIF21 Venture Fund for Software Reuse.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multiphase flows are ubiquitous in nature and industrial processes and examples include rain, ocean waves, atomization and sprays, and bubbles and boiling heat transfer. For many fairly complex multiphase flows, such as when liquid and gas flow together, the mathematical equations describing the motion are known. In most cases they cannot be solved analytically but on powerful computers it is possible to obtain complex solutions for the unsteady motion of many buoyant bubbles, colliding drops and big splashes, where every detail of the flow is resolved. The main limitation on such computations—often referred to as direct numerical simulations—is the large range of scales encountered in practical situations. For bubbly flows, with tens of thousands of bubbles, the computational resources needed are enormous and in many cases non-existing.

To make practical predictions it is therefore common to use simplified mathematical models that describe the average or large scale flow only. When the equations are simplified, however, information are lost and to account for how small scale processes affect the large scale flow we rely on closure models that account approximately for the missing physics. Traditionally closure relations have been obtained using experimental results. Direct numerical simulations of well-defined special cases, that are as large as we can fit on a computer but smaller than full scale industrial systems, give us much more detailed data and allow us to control the setup much more tightly, but result in overwhelming amounts of data that is difficult to process using traditional methods. In the present project we explored the use of machine learning, as currently being developed for problems ranging from customer preferences to voice recognition, to obtain relationships between the various average quantities from the detailed simulation results and showed that the resulting relationships, when used in averaged equations for the same flow as simulated directly, resulted in accurate predictions for the large scale flow. While the systems studied here are relatively simple, the results show the power and promise of this approach.

Although the governing equations for multiphase flows are generally too complex for analytical solutions, we often encounter situations where very small features, such as thin films, threads and tiny drops are formed spontaneously. For those small features, surface tension effects are usually strong enough to keep the geometry simple and viscous effects are strong enough to keep the flow simple. In spite of their simplicity, accurately solving for the dynamics of those features using direct numerical simulations requires considerable computational resources. Analytical and nearly analytical solutions do however exist for some of those features and another objective of the present work was to explore the use of analytical or nearly analytical solutions to capture small features and embed their dynamics in simulations of the rest of the flow. We found that this is, indeed, possible in several cases and results in considerable reduction in needed computational resources. We are currently working on extending the approach to more complex situations.

Dynamic complex heterogeneous systems are found all around us and in addition to multiphase flows as studied here include everyday materials such as concrete and wood, as well as living bodies. The ability to predict the response of systems like those to imposed forces and external and internal changes is critical for estimating the durability of old systems and the design of new ones. The techniques and educational material developed here apply to all such systems and the progress made here should therefore have a broad impact on many fields.
